column3: Description A human or non-human 'thing' that constitutes as an entity
A human or non-human 'thing' that constitutes as an entity and which is recognised and defined in law
A human
The individual or organisation that decides (or controls) the purpose(s) of processing personal data.
column7: The terms 'Controller' is usually the more common form of indicating a Data Controller. In ISO/IEC the term 'PII Controller' is used.

column3: A ‘processor’ means a natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which processes personal data on behalf of the controller.
A 'sub-processor' is a processor engaged by another processor
column7: sub-processor' is a commonly used term similar to 'sub-contractor' and does not have a specific legal definition

column3: Entities that receive personal data
column7: A recipient of personal data can be used to indicate any entity that receives personal data. This can be a Third Party, Processor (GDPR), or even a Controller.

column3: A ‘third party’ means a natural or legal person, public authority, agency or body other than the data subject, controller, processor and people who, under the direct authority of the controller or processor, are authorised to process personal data.

An entity within or authorised by an organisation to monitor internal compliance, inform and advise on data protection obligations and act as a contact point for data subjects and the supervisory authority.
An entity that 'exports' data where exporting is considered a form of data transfer
column7: The EU, in particular the EDPB, uses data exporter the context of cross-border data transfers/flows. These concepts are not bound by jurisdictional or geopolitical scopes within DPV and can thus be used for any notion of exporting
column12: David Hickey, Georg Krog, Paul Ryan, Harshvardhan Pandit

column3: An entity that 'imports' data where importing is considered a form of data transfer
column7: The EU, in particular the EDPB, uses data importing the context of cross-border data transfers/flows. These concepts are not bound by jurisdictional or geopolitical scopes within DPV and can thus be used for any notion of importing
column12: David Hickey, Georg Krog, Paul Ryan, Harshvardhan Pandit

column3: A group of Data Controllers that jointly determine the purposes and means of processing
column7: To indicate the membership, hasDataController may be used

column3: A representative of a legal entity
column12: Georg Krog, Paul Ryan, Harshvardhan J. Pandit, Beatriz Esteves

column3: An authority with the power to create or enforce laws, or determine their compliance.
column12: Georg Krog, Paul Ryan, Harshvardhan Pandit

column3: An authority tasked with overseeing legal compliance regarding privacy and data protection laws.
column12: Georg Krog, Paul Ryan, Harshvardhan Pandit

column3: e.g. DPA, but not all "DPA" are national authority e.g. EDPS and EDPB
e.g. regional DPA in DE / US-CA
e.g. EU, EDPB
The individual (or category of individuals) whose personal data is being processed
column7: The term 'data subject' is specific to the GDPR, but is functionally equivalent to the term 'individual' and the ISO/IEC term 'PII Principle'.

column3: A general term reflecting a company or a business or a group acting as a unit
A consortium established and comprising on industry organisations
An organisation managed or part of government
An organisation not part of or independent from the government
An organisation that aims to achieve profit as its primary goal
An organisation that does not aim to achieve profit as its primary goal
Organisations related to academia or scientific pursuits e.g. Universities, Schools, Research Bodies
A 'child' is a natural legal person who is below a certain legal age depending on the legal jurisdiction.
column7: The legality of age defining a child varies by jurisdiction. In addition, 'child' is distinct from a 'minor'. For example, the legal age drinking alcohol can be 21, which makes a person of age 20 a 'minor' in this context. In other cases, 'minor' and 'child' are used interchangeably to refer to a person below some legally defined age.

column3: Data Subjects which should be considered 'vulnerable' and therefore would require additional measures and safeguards
column12: Georg Krog, Paul Ryan, Harshvardhan Pandit
